title: Question 36

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 63-year-old woman is evaluated at a follow-up visit for a solitary pulmonary nodule. Six months ago CT angiography (CTA) was performed to evaluate a possible pulmonary embolism. The CTA was negative but demonstrated an 8-mm ground-glass (subsolid) nodule in the left upper lobe. The patient has a 15-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but stopped 6 months ago. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs and other examination findings are normal.
A repeat chest CT scan 6 months after the initial scan shows no change in the size or characteristics of the nodule.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

text.__html: Chest CT every 2 years for 5 years

children: An incidentally found ground-glass (subsolid) pulmonary nodule 6 mm or larger necessitates follow-up chest CT at 6 to 12 months; if it persists but is unchanged in size, CT should be repeated at 2-year intervals for 5 years.
The most appropriate management is chest CT every 2 years for 5 years (

). The patient has an indeterminate pulmonary nodule and requires further follow-up evaluation. Pulmonary nodules can be classified as solid or subsolid. The subsolid nodule classification is further subdivided into pure ground-glass nodules and part-solid nodules. The evaluation of pure ground-glass nodules is informed primarily by nodule size. An incidentally found ground-glass nodule of 6 mm or larger necessitates follow-up chest CT at 6 to 12 months. If the nodule persists but is unchanged in size, as in this patient, chest CT should be repeated at 2-year intervals for 5 years. Earlier follow-up is unlikely to affect the outcome of these characteristically indolent lesions. Studies have shown that an average of 3 to 4 years is typically required to establish growth or, less commonly, to diagnose a developing invasive carcinoma. Many ground-glass nodules resolve spontaneously because they can also be from infectious or inflammatory causes. If the nodule resolves, no further follow-up is needed. If the nodule grows or develops a solid component, biopsy or resection is recommended.

Ground-glass nodules are associated with more indolent histologic lesions (e.g., adenocarcinoma in situ and minimally invasive adenocarcinoma), which require longer follow-up to determine whether they are benign. Thus, it is not appropriate to perform follow-up CT at 12 months (
) with no further testing if the scan is normal.
The indolence of ground-glass nodules and their very low metabolic activity also makes fluorodeoxyglucose PET less useful (
); PET scans in this setting can show false-positive results.
) would not be recommended at this point because it would subject the patient to a surgery that may be unnecessary given the indeterminate nature of the nodule.

objective.__html: Evaluate an 8-mm ground-glass (subsolid) pulmonary nodule with serial CT scans.

references: MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for management of incidental pulmonary nodules detected on CT images: from the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. 2017;284:228-243.
